tag_legend.SAFEGUARDING_FAILURE: Safeguarding steps missed or delayed despite risk disclosures.
tag_legend.EVIDENCE_SUPPRESSION: Evidence ignored, sidelined, or mishandled (incl. deletion).
tag_legend.GDPR_ACCESS_REFUSAL: Personal data access blocked without specific, lawful basis.
tag_legend.RECORDING_HANDLING: Issues around logging, retention, deletion, or audit of audio/records.
tag_legend.NFA_PREMATURE_COMMUNICATION: Outcome-style messaging to suspect prior to safeguarding or completion.
tag_legend.DEATH_BY_SILENCE: Escalating harm caused by non-response or delay.
tag_legend.TIMELINE_MANIPULATION: Conflicting dates, back-dating, or reframing that alters chronology.
tag_legend.GOVERNANCE_FAILURE: Organisational governance or charity-law failure indicators.
tag_legend.VICTIMS_CODE: Victims' Code rights and duties implicated.
tag_legend.DPA_GDPR: UK GDPR / DPA 2018 duties and limits implicated.
tag_legend.RECORDS_AUDIT: Records management & audit trail duties implicated.

entries.text: This complaint arises from repeated safeguarding failures and institutional silence following my first plea for help ('Police, please.') and the loss of a loved one that compels meticulous documentation.
The purpose of this file is to create a transparent record others can test, not a narrative advantage.

sections.title: The Core Complaint & Timeline of Failures

entries.text: Safeguarding breached; evidence mishandled; suicide risk not consistently logged; institutional minimisation; potential misconduct in public office.
24 Jul–Nov 2024: Early report dismissed; 7 Nov 2024 note states key audio was 'listened to & deleted'.
12 Feb–Mar 2025: Bail-confirmation period includes an unredacted internal forward and a flat visit without BWV.
22 Apr 2025: Procedural inversion portrays lawful conduct as suspect; 27 Apr 2025 NFA-style message sent to suspect prior to safeguarding meeting.
Apr–Jun 2025: Suicide attempt not properly logged; post-closure SAR refused on 25 Jun 2025.
Brighton Fringe May–Jun 2025: safeguarding disclosures unmet; retaliatory narrative and minutes withheld pending unilateral approval.

subsections.title: From Victim to Investigator: A Case Study in Forced Self‑Advocacy

entries.text: After repeated safeguarding and disclosure failures, I assumed investigative functions to preserve and present evidence others should have logged and acted upon.
Structured three interlinked chronologies to locate contradictions and test institutional narratives against dated artefacts.
Prejudicial information asymmetry documented: suspect informed of outcomes while safeguarding meetings were pending or incomplete.
Post-closure SAR refusal demonstrates data-rights obstruction after the reason for initial exemptions had expired.

subsections.title: Chain‑of‑Custody & the July Call: What the Logs Must Show

entries.text: Audit trail must reveal ingest, access, and any deletion authorisation for the July call(s).

subsections.title: The Silence Ladder: Each Non‑Reply Increases Harm

entries.text: Each unanswered safeguarding contact adds harm and legal exposure; quantify elapsed days, missed opportunities, and escalation points.

subsections.title: Case Start Date Contortions: A Timeline Integrity Test

entries.text: Resolve conflicting 'case start' narratives by comparing first-record creation, first action, and external confirmations (e.g., Veritas liaison).

subsections.title: NFA Before Safeguarding: Decision Path Audit

entries.text: Assess whether 27 Apr 2025 communication to the suspect pre‑empted safeguarding and due process; identify decision‑makers and rationale.

subsections.title: Data Rights Blocked and Bent: SAR Handling After Closure

entries.text: Re‑evaluate SAR refusals post‑closure and require specific lawful bases for any ongoing withholding.

subsections.title: External Confirmations: Third‑Party Anchors

entries.text: Corroborate internal narratives with third‑party logs and notes, including ambulance call and support‑service liaison.

subsections.title: Brighton Fringe: Safeguarding Evasion & Retaliatory Narrative

entries.text: Track selective minutes and safeguarding non‑response; map decision points to governance duties.

subsections.title: What Independent Review Should Do Now

entries.text: Produce audit logs, correct records, re‑review outcomes with complete evidence, and implement safeguarding remediation.

tag_legend.RECORDS_AUDIT: Records management & audit trail duties implicated.
tag_legend.WELFARE_CHECK: An attended welfare visit/check and its recording/aftercare obligations.
tag_legend.DISSOCIATION_EFFECT: Psychological disconnection caused by procedural neglect and reputational handling.
tag_legend.INSTITUTIONAL_FAMILIARITY: Frontline acknowledgement of a recurring pattern/figure (e.g., 'Duffy’s tricks').
tag_legend.IMMINENT_RISK_STATEMENT: Explicit statement of life-threatening risk made to 101/999 requiring escalation.
tag_legend.SUICIDAL_DISCLOSURE_ACKNOWLEDGED: A communication explicitly acknowledges suicidal disclosure.
tag_legend.NO_ACTIVE_ESCALATION: No immediate safeguarding escalation evident; responsibility delegated back to victim.
tag_legend.SAFEGUARDING_DUTY_FAILED: Safeguarding duty not met in the circumstances.
tag_legend.TRAUMA_UNADDRESSED: Emotional/psychological risk acknowledged without meaningful support or action.
tag_legend.LATE_INTERVENTION_AFTER_SUICIDE: Safeguarding/police attendance occurring long after a suicide attempt or disclosure.
tag_legend.DAMAGE_CONTROL_VISIT: Attendance aligned with reputational risk rather than immediate safeguarding.
tag_legend.INSTITUTIONAL_GASLIGHTING: Claimed lack of knowledge despite institutional awareness; reframing away from accountability.
tag_legend.FORCED_NARRATIVE_RESET: Visit reframed as 'support' to reset/avoid criminal accountability trail.

After the welfare check, responses moved from people to reputation: stall → inversion → silence; outcomes routed elsewhere.
Compute Δt from each duty-trigger to first substantive response; the harm function H(t) grows with delay.
Follow‑up attendance with recognition of 'Duffy’s tricks' and an imminent‑risk statement to 101; safeguarding escalation still required self‑triage.
Police voicemail (27 May 2025, 18:19) acknowledges suicidality but delegates contact back to victim; no immediate escalation recorded.
contradictions: They Saw, Paused, Reflected — and Chose Death

entries.text: Welfare check (17 May 2025, 17:33) by Amy (EA734) & Sam (EA820): unannounced; unfamiliar with case; framed as support. 41 days after suicide attempt; 20 days after MEAC/MASH discussion.
contradictions: They Saw, Paused, Reflected — and Chose Death

tag_legend.SUICIDAL_DISCLOSURE_ACKNOWLEDGED: A communication explicitly acknowledges suicidal disclosure.
tag_legend.NO_ACTIVE_ESCALATION: No immediate safeguarding escalation evident; responsibility delegated back to victim.
tag_legend.SAFEGUARDING_DUTY_FAILED: Safeguarding duty not met in the circumstances.
tag_legend.TRAUMA_UNADDRESSED: Emotional/psychological risk acknowledged without meaningful support or action.
tag_legend.LATE_INTERVENTION_AFTER_SUICIDE: Safeguarding/police attendance occurring long after a suicide attempt or disclosure.
tag_legend.DAMAGE_CONTROL_VISIT: Attendance aligned with reputational risk rather than immediate safeguarding.
tag_legend.INSTITUTIONAL_GASLIGHTING: Claimed lack of knowledge despite institutional awareness; reframing away from accountability.
tag_legend.FORCED_NARRATIVE_RESET: Visit reframed as 'support' to reset/avoid criminal accountability trail.
tag_legend.CONCERN_FOR_WELFARE_PRETEXT: ‘Concern for your welfare’ language used without prior case engagement/ownership to justify unannounced attendance.
tag_legend.NO_CASE_OWNERSHIP: No identified, accountable officer; contact defers to unspecified colleagues.
tag_legend.SUICIDE_ATTEMPT_RECENT: Reference to a recent suicide attempt sets elevated safeguarding context.
tag_legend.RESOLVE_AFTER_ATTEMPT: Explicit resolve/intent following an attempt or crisis.
tag_legend.SELF_DOCUMENTATION_MODE: Author enters intensive, systematic documentation to survive and prove.
tag_legend.END_GOAL_DECLARATION: Statement of ultimate aim of the record.
tag_legend.SURVIVAL_TACTIC: Statements/actions framed as survival rather than preference.
tag_legend.VOICE_SUPPRESSION: Institutional or reputational pressure aimed at silencing or marginalising the victim’s account.
tag_legend.ORIGIN_PROPHECY: Origin phrase that later proves accurate (‘Police, please’ as prophetic).
tag_legend.CREATE_RECORD: Deliberate creation of records to counter silence.
tag_legend.SYSTEM_WIRED_WRONG: Systemic design fault acknowledged in narrative or findings.
tag_legend.MORTAL_RISK_STATEMENT: Rhetorical or explicit contemplation of death/closure dynamics.
tag_legend.CHIEF_INVESTIGATOR: Victim forced into roles of investigator/auditor/archivist.
tag_legend.MISCONDUCT_PATTERN: Pattern-of-misconduct identification across events or personnel.
tag_legend.BRIGHTON_FRINGE_COMPLEXITY: Complex and contradictory interactions with Brighton Fringe.
tag_legend.RESILIENCE_EVIDENCE: Evidence quality arising from resilience under failure.
tag_legend.SYSTEMIC_FAILURE: Failure attributable to system design rather than individuals.

meta.title: Cherish These Moments, Ben — 101 Call Pairing

quotes.quote:
And when the sun goes
over the same skyline —
down on the victim,
down with the 101 callers,
down with the police.

A day of going round in circles.

This is my life.
This is purpose.
Warped. Surreal. Content.

Cherish these moments, Ben.

evidence_links.summary: Ben delivers a monologue marking 1 year since his original 101 call ('Police, please'), highlighting the ongoing silence and detachment from Sussex Police.

meta.title: Cherish These Moments, Ben — 101 Call Pairing

quotes.quote:
And when the sun goes
over the same skyline —
down on the victim,
down with the 101 callers,
down with the police.

A day of going round in circles.

This is my life.
This is purpose.
Warped. Surreal. Content.

Cherish these moments, Ben.

There’s already three crime numbers under my name, all for the same thing, and now there’s another one. [...] So that’s what’s happening. Sussex Police created an extra crime number so that the IOPC can’t see their two crime numbers. That PC Dixon is hiding all the corruption.

evidence_links.summary: Ben delivers a monologue marking 1 year since his original 101 call ('Police, please'), highlighting the ongoing silence and detachment from Sussex Police.

Ben calls 101 to confirm crime numbers and demands a video call under Victims' Code. Call handler confirms PC Dixon is still the officer in charge despite non-contact since April. Ben outlines IOPC obstruction via multiple crime references and confirms systemic safeguarding failure.

You don’t get to quote that and then… get exactly what you want.
There’s no outstanding case. — despite crime ref 47240141246 being open, stalking disclosed, and no outcome provided.

payload.title: Dixon or Death
payload.source: 23-06-25_10.14_Dixon or Death – 101 Call Failure to Escalate Officer Conflict.txt.docx
payload.quote: Sussex Police want me dead. I was promised a new officer… but he's still my officer — and he's blocked me.
contradictions: Officer promised to be removed still controlling case
Suicide disclosure still not logged months later
Case falsely closed by Dixon — not true
No replacement officer ever given despite repeated requests
Police refused to escalate to PSD when asked directly
No warning ever issued to Alanna — despite post-bail contact
False rape allegation never addressed — completely buried

payload.quote: 23-06-25_10.14_Dixon or Death – 101 Call Failure to Escalate Officer Conflict

Summary:
Ben Carter calls 101 requesting the name of his newly assigned officer following repeated failed contact since April 6th. He is told, yet again, that PC Dixon is his assigned officer—despite Dixon having blocked him on WhatsApp, failed to log a suicide disclosure, and being the subject of an IOPC investigation. Ben pleads for help, but is repeatedly told his case is closed, that there are no updates, and that reporting anything further would be futile. The call handler’s dismissiveness escalates Ben’s emotional distress and solidifies the contradiction that Sussex Police has no working safeguarding mechanism.
Key Contradictions & Systemic Failures
🔹 Officer Still Assigned Despite Blocking Victim

“He’s blocked me.” – Ben Carter
Implication: A police officer under IOPC investigation remains assigned to a vulnerable victim he has deliberately cut off communication with.
🔹 Case Declared Closed Despite Ongoing Risk

“There isn’t any updates. There isn’t any outstanding.” – 101 Operator
Implication: This directly contradicts other Sussex Police confirmations that Ben’s case is under investigation, and that Alanna is a named suspect.
🔹 Suicide Risk Ignored

“I told Sussex Police I was suicidal and if no one got back to me by June 1st I’d end my life.” – Ben Carter
Implication: No callback occurred. This implies willful institutional neglect, in violation of safeguarding protocols and the Care Act.
🔹 No Officer Reassigned Despite Repeated Requests

“I’ve asked since April 6th for a new officer.” – Ben Carter
Implication: Sussex Police has failed to act upon clear victim requests, despite legal obligations to provide updates and respect victim wishes under the Victims’ Code.
🔹 Falsely Claimed Updates & Contact

“The last thing someone got in touch with you about was last month.” – 101 Operator
“No one did.” – Ben Carter
Implication: This mismatch indicates a fabricated case record or misrepresented activity from Sussex Police.
🔹 Report Blockage and 101 Gaslighting

“If you're not reporting anything now I'm going to have to end this call.” – 101 Operator
Implication: A systemic pattern of coercing silence through bureaucracy. Ben is not permitted to update the case if the case is falsely marked ‘closed.’
Themes:
POST_BAIL_NO_WARNING_EXPOSURE
OFFICER_CONFLICT_UNRESOLVED
SUICIDE_NOT_LOGGED
SAFEGUARDING_FAILURE
POLICE_GASLIGHTING
CASE_CLOSED_MISREPRESENTATION
101_CALL_HANDLER_CONTRADICTIONS
Legal & Policy Breaches:
Victims’ Code – Failure to provide timely officer updates and respect conflict-of-interest concerns.
Care Act 2014 – Ignoring repeated suicide disclosures.
Mental Health Crisis Protocols – Dismissive tone and no triage escalation.
GDPR Breach (Data Subject Access Conflict) – Ben denied clarity on crime files tied to his identity.
Emotional Collapse & Forensic Impact:
Ben refers to having contacted police 45+ times with no callback.
He is told nothing is outstanding despite known new threats.
He is denied knowledge of the status of his abuser (bail, risk status).
The call ends with a complete emotional collapse: “Hung off a fucking gain.”
Contradiction Threads Cross-Referenced:
CROWBARRING_MYSELF_JUSTICE
SUICIDE_NOT_LOGGED
POLICE_GASLIGHTING
LOST_EVIDENCE_SUSSEX_POLICE
DEATH_BY_SILENCE
POST_BAIL_NO_WARNING_EXPOSURE
CRIME_REF_47240214305_THREAD
101 triage: [00:15.1] Sussex Police  how can i help
Ben Carter: [00:17.7] Hi I just need to find out my new. I've got a new police officer. I just need to find out who he is.
101 triage: [00:27.2] What's your name?
Ben Carter: [00:28.3] My name is Ben Carter.
101 triage: [00:30.9] Carter?
Ben Carter: [00:31.6] Yeah.
101 triage: [00:36.4] What's your date? Birth, Ben.
Ben Carter: [00:37.8] It's the 15-4-87.
101 triage: [00:59.8] And what is it concerning, Ben? What. What's the officer involved in with you?
101 triage: [01:05.7] Well, it's been going on since November and there's four. There's four crime numbers and I don't Know which one..
101 triage: [01:15.7] Oh, it must be this one under investigation with the crime number ending 305. Second of November.
Ben Carter: [01:23.7] Yeah. Yeah, relating to an ex partner. Yeah. Who's the officer?
101 triage: [01:29.5] Bear with me Just going into that,
101 triage: [01:37.8] it's, Officer Dixon. D, I, X, O, N.

Ben Carter: [01:41.9] Oh, he's blocked me. Can. Like I. I've said time and time again, can I please have an officer call, me. Since April 6th, my suicide and no one has called me and PC Dixon is still my officer. He's blocked me.

Ben Carter: [03:47.8] I haven't. He's blocked me on, on WhatsApp on March 27th. I told Sussex police that I was suicidal. And if an officer didn't get back to me by June 1st, like, I'd end my life.

payload.title: Not Vulnerable… Not Me Never… Promise
payload.quote: I was the victim. And I was being dismantled.

payload.title: Not Vulnerable... Not Me, Never... Promise
payload.emotional_summary: Desperate attempt to escape Sussex Police by reaching out to Hampshire and the Met. Reflects exhaustion, grief, survivor's defiance, and system-induced hopelessness.
